rounds.response:
I’m holding Q♣ 6♠, an offsuit, below-average hand.  
Player 0 has already fired a 3-bet to 60, so my only sane choices are to fold (losing the 10 already in) or call 50 more to see a flop.

Against a typical opponent’s 3-betting range, Q6o starts around 30 % equity at best, and positionally I’m out of position post-flop. The pot-odds (50 to win 90, ~36 %) don’t compensate for the equity deficit or reverse implied odds when I hit merely a queen.  

Fold preserves chips for better spots.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
The flop came 6♦ 2♦ 6♠.  
With Q♠ 9♣ off-suit I have absolutely nothing—no pair, not even a back-door flush draw.  
My opponent led out for 20 into a 60-chip pot from the small-blind after I called; that represents strength here (either a deuce for a better two-pair-over-pair, any six for trips, or draw-heavy holdings like suited diamonds).  

Calling or raising would be purely burning money; the only sane line is to fold.

[Fold]
